texts.orig: UPDATE:  The fixed version of mutter is now in the Fedora updates repository. You should be able to update the package with
texts.text: UPDATE:  The fixed version of mutter is now in the Fedora updates repository. You should be able to update the package with

texts.label: text
texts.orig: GNOME 3 has been rock solid for the last few months but something cropped up this week that derailed me for a short while. Whenever I moved my mouse cursor to the top bar (where the clock and status icons reside), the mouse cursor disappeared. The same thing happened if I pressed the Mod/Windows key to hop into the Activities display.
texts.text: GNOME 3 has been rock solid for the last few months but something cropped up this week that derailed me for a short while. Whenever I moved my mouse cursor to the top bar (where the clock and status icons reside), the mouse cursor disappeared. The same thing happened if I pressed the Mod/Windows key to hop into the Activities display.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If I wiggled the mouse a bit, I could see the highlight move around to different windows and icons. The mouse cursor never appeared.
texts.text: If I wiggled the mouse a bit, I could see the highlight move around to different windows and icons. The mouse cursor never appeared.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Lots of Google results led to dead ends. I stumbled onto a  GNOME bug for gnome-shell  from early 2015 that seemed to cover the same problem. After adding in my comments, I created a  Fedora bug  to track the problem.
texts.text: Lots of Google results led to dead ends. I stumbled onto a  GNOME bug for gnome-shell  from early 2015 that seemed to cover the same problem. After adding in my comments, I created a  Fedora bug  to track the problem.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Around that time, Florian Müllner replied in the GNOME bug about trying
texts.text: Around that time, Florian Müllner replied in the GNOME bug about trying

texts.label: text
texts.orig: at the time. The  new version of mutter  was still in the  pending  state in Fedora's packaging infrastructure, so I pulled it down with
texts.text: at the time. The  new version of mutter  was still in the  pending  state in Fedora's packaging infrastructure, so I pulled it down with

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
koji download-build --arch x86_64 mutter-3.18.3-2.fc23
sudo dnf install mutter-3.18.3-2.fc23.x86_64.rpm
texts.text:
koji download-build --arch x86_64 mutter-3.18.3-2.fc23
sudo dnf install mutter-3.18.3-2.fc23.x86_64.rpm

texts.label: text
texts.orig: After a reboot, everything was back to normal! The cursor appears reliably in the top bar, Activities screen, and other overlays. In addition, some of the transient cursor weirdness I had with some applications seems to be gone.
texts.text: After a reboot, everything was back to normal! The cursor appears reliably in the top bar, Activities screen, and other overlays. In addition, some of the transient cursor weirdness I had with some applications seems to be gone.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: UPDATE:   Jiří Eischmann  tweeted yesterday about this problem:
texts.text: UPDATE:   Jiří Eischmann  tweeted yesterday about this problem:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: @majorhayden I was hit by that too. But it only occurs when 0:0's not visible, when left monitor is below the right, so not so many ppl impt
texts.text: @majorhayden I was hit by that too. But it only occurs when 0:0's not visible, when left monitor is below the right, so not so many ppl impt

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In my particular case, my "left" monitor is my laptop screen and my "right" monitor is my external display. I configure the external monitor to be  above  my laptop monitor physically and logically, which is why the problem appears for me. Thanks for the clarification, Jiří!
texts.text: In my particular case, my "left" monitor is my laptop screen and my "right" monitor is my external display. I configure the external monitor to be  above  my laptop monitor physically and logically, which is why the problem appears for me. Thanks for the clarification, Jiří!
